sentence: How much of Oracle’s (ORCL) total revenue will be made up by its Cloud business?
Is the database giant exiting its core legacy database business too quickly?
And to what extent can the former make up the difference in the company’s bottom line?
These are the pressing questions investors will focus on when Oracle reports third quarter fiscal 2017 earnings after the closing Wednesday.

The Redwood City, Calif.-based tech giant, which continues to invest more on its transition to the Cloud to offset weak licensing revenues, is expected to report a decline in profits when it reports fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market closes on Wednesday.
Oracle CEO Larry Ellison has waged the company’s future on its ability to catch up to or eventually pass the likes of Salesforce.com (CRM) and Microsoft (MSFT).

Fresh off its $9.3 billion acquisition of Cloud-software company NetSuite, a deal that passed a shareholder vote in November, Ellison is leaving no stones unturned to get revenue growing back into the "mid-teens" area, where analysts will be forced to take the company more seriously.
To that end, Wall Street will focus on the company’s licensing businesses, which declined 19% in the second quarter.
Any improvement, or a more modest decline, would be well received by investors.
For the quarter that ended February, analysts on average expect Oracle to report adjusted earnings of 62 cents per share on revenue of $9.22 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earning were 64 cents per share on $9.01 billion in revenue.
For the full year, ending May, earnings are projected to be $2.56 per share, down from $2.61 a year ago, while revenue of $37.54 billion would rise 1.3% year over year.
How will ORCL stock, which closed Tuesday at $42.79, react to these numbers?
The shares have gained about 5% in the past three months and 11.29% over the past year.
This compares with a 19% one-year rise for the S&P 500.
The stock has a consensus Buy rating and an average analyst 12-month price target of $45, suggesting 5% premium from current levels.
While the 5% return from excite investors, Oracle still generates tons of cash flow and is actively buying back shares.
And from a valuation perspective, you would be hard-pressed to find a better bargain, risk-averse large-cap tech name.
ORCL stock is priced at a forward P/E ratio of 15, or four points below the S&P 500 SPX index.
Assuming the shares were priced in-line with the rest of the market, they would trade today at around $52, or 20% higher.
And with Ellison mashing the accelerator towards the Cloud, ORCL stock should be owned for the next 12 to 18 months.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
